questions.question: Which of the following is a nucleus of basal ganglia?
Which part of the basal ganglia receives the afferent input?
questions.explanation: The striatum receives the afferent input.Note:There are two main inputs to the basal ganglia: From the cerebral cortex (corticostriate pathway)and from the thalamus (thalamostriate pathway). They are both excitatory (glutamate) and theyboth terminate in the striatum.The two major outputs of the basal ganglia are from GPi and substantia nigra. Both are inhibitory(GABAergic) and both project to the thalamus.From the thalamus, there is an excitatory (glutamatergic) projection to the prefrontal andpremotor cortex. questions.question: Efferent from cerebellar cortex is through which cell:
questions.explanation: Purkinje cells are the only output neurons (efferent neurons) from the cerebellar cortex.The Purkinje cells are the largest neurons in the cerebellum. Their axons, which are the onlyoutput from the cerebellar cortex, project to the deep cerebellar nuclei, especially the dentatenucleus, where they form inhibitory synapses.

questions.question: Flocculonodular lobe has direct connections with
questions.explanation: The flocculonodular lobe has connections with the vestibular apparatus. The flocculonodular lobe forms the vestibulocerebellum, which projects to the vestibular nuclei and is concerned with equilibrium and eye movements.

questions.question: Which of the following is a function of the neocerebellum?

options.C: Planning and programming of voluntary movements309

questions.explanation: The function of the neocerebellum is planning and programming of voluntary movements.The cerebellum can be divided into:The Vestibulocerebellum/Archicerebellum: Consists principally of the flocculonodular lobe andadjacent portions of the vermis. It participates in balance, vestibular reflexes, and eye movements.The Spinocerebellum/Paleocerebellum: Consists of most of the vermis plus the adjacentintermediate zones on both sides of the vermis. It coordinates movements of the limbs. Vermis:Proximal muscles, Intermediate zones: Distal musclesThe Cerebrocerebellum/neocerebellum: Consists of the large lateral zones of the cerebellarhemispheres. It receives all its input from the cerebral cortex (motor, premotor andsomatosensory). It transmits its output back to the brain, functioning in a feedback manner toplan sequential voluntary body and limb movements.

questions.question: A patient with a cerebellar lesion will show all of the following features except:
questions.explanation: A patient with a suspected cerebellar lesion will not have resting tremors. Resting tremors arecharacteristic features of basal ganglia lesions. (Parkinson's disease).318Intentional tremors are seen in cerebellar diseases.Features of cerebellar disease• Ataxia - Incoordinated, intermittent jerky movements with drunken gait.• Hypotonia or atonia - Reduced or absence of muscle tone.• Dysmetria – Inability to judge the force and range of movement resulting in past pointing.-• Dysdiadokokinesia - Failure to perform rapid alternating movements.••Decomposition of movement - Lack of smooth flow of movement.Speech defect - Staccato speech or slurring speech.• Pendular knee jerk (a feature of hypotonia).• Intention tremors.• Nystagmus (jerky movements of the eye).•Rebound phenomenon.

questions.question: 311Concerning the circuitry between mossy fibers, climbing fibers and cells of the cerebellarcortex, which of the following pairs provide excitatory input?

options.C: Granule cell parallel fibers and mossy fibers

questions.explanation: The excitatory fibers in the cerebellum are climbing fibers, mossy fibers, and granule cell parallelfibers.The fundamental circuits of the cerebellar cortex :•Climbing fibers exert a strong excitatory effect on single Purkinje cells. Mossy fibers exert anexcitatory effect on granule cells.•• Each granule cell sends an axon to the molecular layer, where the axon bifurcates to form a T.The branches of the T are straight and run long distances; thus, they are called parallel fibers. Theparallel fibers form excitatory synapses on the dendrites of many Purkinje cells.• The other neurons (basket cells, stellate cells, and golgi cells) are inhibitory interneurons. Basketcells and stellate cells receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and each inhibits manyPurkinje cells. Golgi cells receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and mossy fibers. Theiraxons project to the dendrites of the granule cells where they form an inhibitory synapse.• The output of the Purkinje cells is ultimately inhibitory to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.question: Inhibition of Purkinje cells by stellate cells is an example of

options.D: Stellate cells doesn't inhibit purkinje cells

questions.explanation: Inhibition of Purkinje cells by stellate cells is an example of feedforward inhibition.Mossy fibers exert a weak excitatory effect on many Purkinje cells via the granule cells. Thegranule cells also excite the basket and stellate cells via their parallel fibers. The basket andstellate cells, in turn, inhibit the Purkinje cells (Feed forward inhibition).Renshaw cells exhibit feedback inhibition.320
